title: The Comedie of Errors from Mr. William Shakespeares comedies, histories, & tragedies. Published according to the true originall copies.

characters.name: Aemilia, wife to Aegeon, an abbess at Ephesus
Adriana, wife to Antipholus of Ephesus
Antipholus of Syracuse, twin brother of Antipholus of Ephesus, son to Aegeon and Aemelia
Dromio of Syracuse, twin brother to Dromio of Ephesus, and attendant on the two Antipholuses
Antipholus of Ephesus, twin brother of Antipholus of Syracuse, son to Aegeon and Aemilia
Dromio of Ephesus, twin brother to Dromio of Syracuse, and attendant on the two Antipholuses

lines.speaker: Marchant.
lines.text: PRoceed {% italic: Solinus %} to procure my fall,

lines.speaker: Marchant.
lines.text: And by the doome of death end woes and all.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Merchant of {% italic: Siracusa %}, plead no more.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: I am not partiall to infringe our Lawes;

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: The enmity and discord which of late

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your Duke,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: To Merchants our well‑dealing Countrimen,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Who wanting gilders to redeeme their liues,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Haue seal'd his rigorous statutes with their blouds,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Excludes all pitty from our threatning lookes:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: For since the mortall and intestine iarres

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Twixt thy seditious Countrimen and vs,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: It hath in solemne Synodes beene decreed,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Both by the {% italic: Siracusians %} and our selues,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: To admit no trafficke to our aduerse townes:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Nay more, if any borne at {% italic: Ephesus %}

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Be seene at any {% italic: Siracusian %} Marts and Fayres:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Againe, if any {% italic: Siracusian %} borne

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Come to the Bay of {% italic: Ephesus %}, he dies:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: His goods confiscate to the Dukes dispose,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Vnlesse a thousand markes be leuied

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: To quit the penalty, and to ransome him:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Thy substance, valued at the highest rate,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Cannot amount vnto a hundred Markes,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Therefore by Law thou art condemn'd to die.

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Yet this my comfort, when your words are done,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: My woes end likewise with the euening Sonne.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Well {% italic: Siracusian %}; say in briefe the cause

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Why thou departedst from thy natiue home?

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: And for what cause thou cam'st to {% italic: Ephesus. %}

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: A heauier taske could not haue beene impos'd,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Then I to speake my griefes vnspeakeable:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Yet that the world may witnesse that my end

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Was wrought by nature, not by vile offence,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Ile vtter what my sorrow giues me leaue.

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: In {% italic: Syracusa %} was I borne, and wedde

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Vnto a woman, happy but for me,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: And by me; had not our hap beene bad:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: With her I liu'd in ioy, our wealth increast

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: By prosperous voyages I often made

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: To {% italic: Epidamium %}, till my factors death,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: And he great care of goods at randone left,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Drew me from kinde embracements of my spouse;

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: From whom my absence was not sixe moneths olde,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Before her selfe (almost at fainting vnder

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: The pleasing punishment that women beare)

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Had made prouision for her following me,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: And soone, and safe, arriued where I was:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: There had she not beene long, but she became

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: A ioyfull mother of two goodly sonnes:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: And, which was strange, the one so like the other,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: As could not be distinguish'd but by names.

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: That very howre, and in the selfe‑same Inne,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: A meane woman was deliuered

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Of such a burthen Male, twins both alike:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Those, for their parents were exceeding poore,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: I bought, and brought vp to attend my sonnes.

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: My wife, not meanely prowd of two such boyes,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Made daily motions for our home returne:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Vnwilling I agreed, alas, too soone wee came aboord.

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: A league from {% italic: Epidamium %} had we saild

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Before the alwaies winde‑obeying deepe

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Gaue any Tragicke Instance of our harme:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: But longer did we not retaine much hope;

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: For what obscured light the heauens did grant,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Did but conuay vnto our fearefull mindes

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: A doubtfull warrant of immediate death,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Which though my selfe would gladly haue imbrac'd,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Yet the incessant weepings of my wife,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Weeping before for what she saw must come,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: And pitteous playnings of the prettie babes

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: That mourn'd for fashion, ignorant what to feare,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Forst me to seeke delayes for them and me,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: And this it was: (for other meanes was none)

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: The Sailors sought for safety by our boate,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: And left the ship then sinking ripe to vs.

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: My wife, more carefull for the latter borne,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Had fastned him vnto a small spare Mast,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Such as sea‑faring men prouide for stormes:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: To him one of the other twins was bound,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Whil'st I had beene like heedfull of the other.

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: The children thus dispos'd, my wife and I,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fixt,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Fastned our selues at eyther end the mast,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: And floating straight, obedient to the streame,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Was carried towards {% italic: Corinth %}, as we thought.

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: At length the sonne gazing vpon the earth,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Disperst those vapours that offended vs,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: And by the benefit of his wished light

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: The seas waxt calme, and we discouered

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Two shippes from farre, making amaine to vs:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Of {% italic: Corinth %} that, of {% italic: Epidarus %} this,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: But ere they came, oh let me say no more,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Gather the sequell by that went before.

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: Nay forward old man, doe not breake off so,

lines.speaker: Duk.
lines.text: For we may pitty, though not pardon thee.

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Oh had the gods done so, I had not now

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Worthily tearm'd them mercilesse to vs:

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: For ere the ships could meet by twice fiue leagues,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: We were encountred by a mighty rocke,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Which being violently borne vp,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Our helpefull ship was splitted in the midst;

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: So that in this vniust diuorce of vs,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Fortune had left to both of vs alike,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: What to delight in, what to sorrow for,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Her part, poore soule, seeming as burdened

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: With lesser waight, but not with lesser woe,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Was carried with more speed before the winde,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: And in our sight they three were taken vp

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: By Fishermen of {% italic: Corinth %}, as we thought.

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: At length another ship had seiz'd on vs,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: And knowing whom it was their hap to saue,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Gaue healthfull welcome to their ship‑wrackt guests,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: And would haue reft the Fishers of their prey,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Had not their backe beene very slow of saile;

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: And therefore homeward did they bend their course.

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Thus haue you heard me seuer'd from my blisse,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: That by misfortunes was my life prolong'd,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: To tell sad stories of my owne mishaps.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Doe me the fauour to dilate at full,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: What haue befalne of them and they till now.

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: My yongest boy, and yet my eldest care,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: At eighteene yeeres became inquisitiue

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: After his brother; and importun'd me

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: That his attendant, so his case was like,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Reft of his brother, but retain'd his name,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Might beare him company in the quest of him:

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Whom whil'st I laboured of a loue to see,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: I hazarded the losse of whom I lou'd.

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Fiue Sommers haue I spent in farthest {% italic: Greece %},

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Roming cleane through the bounds of {% italic: Asia %},

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: And coasting homeward, came to {% italic: Ephesus: %}

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Hopelesse to finde, yet loth to leaue vnsought

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Or that, or any place that harbours men:

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: But heere must end the story of my life,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: And happy were I in my timelie death,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Could all my trauells warrant me they liue.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Haplesse {% italic: Egeon %} whom the fates haue markt

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: To beare the extremitie of dire mishap:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Now trust me, were it not against our Lawes,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Against my Crowne, my oath, my dignity,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Which Princes would they may not disanull,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: My soule should sue as aduocate for thee:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: But though thou art adiudged to the death,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: And passed sentence may not be recal'd

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: But to our honours great disparagement:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Yet will I fauour thee in what I can;

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Therefore Marchant, Ile limit thee this day

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: To seeke thy helpe by beneficiall helpe,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Try all the friends thou hast in {% italic: Ephesus %},

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Beg thou, or borrow, to make vp the summe,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: And liue: if no, then thou art doom'd to die:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Iaylor, take him to thy custodie.

lines.speaker: Iaylor.
lines.text: I will my Lord.

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: Hopelesse and helpelesse doth {% italic: Egean %} wend,

lines.speaker: Merch.
lines.text: But to procrastinate his liuelesse end.

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Therefore giue out you are of {% italic: Epidamium %},

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Lest that your goods too soone be confiscate:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: This very day a {% italic: Syracusian %} Marchant

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Is apprehended for a riuall here,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: And not being able to buy out his life,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: According to the statute of the towne,

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: Dies ere the wearie sunne set in the West:

lines.speaker: Mer.
lines.text: There is your monie that I had to keepe.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Goe beare it to the Centaure, where we host,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: And stay there {% italic: Dromio %}, till I come to thee;

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Within this houre it will be dinner time,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Till that Ile view the manners of the towne,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Peruse the traders, gaze vpon the buildings,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: And then returne and sleepe within mine Inne,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: For with long trauaile I am stiffe and wearie.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Get thee away.

lines.speaker: Dro.
lines.text: Many a man would take you at your word,

lines.speaker: Dro.
lines.text: And goe indeede, hauing so good a meane.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: A trustie villaine sir, that very oft,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: When I am dull with care and melancholly,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Lightens my humour with his merry iests:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: What will you walke with me about the towne,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: And then goe to my Inne and dine with me?

lines.speaker: E. Mar.
lines.text: I am inuited sir to certaine Marchants,

lines.speaker: E. Mar.
lines.text: Of whom I hope to make much benefit:

lines.speaker: E. Mar.
lines.text: I craue your pardon, soone at fiue a clocke,

lines.speaker: E. Mar.
lines.text: Please you, Ile meete with you vpon the Mart,

lines.speaker: E. Mar.
lines.text: And afterward consort you till bed time:

lines.speaker: E. Mar.
lines.text: My present businesse cals me from you now.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Farewell till then: I will goe loose my selfe,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: And wander vp and downe to view the Citie.

lines.speaker: E. Mar.
lines.text: Sir, I commend you to your owne content.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: He that commends me to mine owne content,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Commends me to the thing I cannot get:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: I to the world am like a drop of water,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: That in the Ocean seekes another drop,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Who falling there to finde his fellow forth,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: (Vnseene, inquisitiue) confounds himselfe.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: So I, to finde a Mother and a Brother,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: In quest of them (vnhappie a) loose my selfe.

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Return'd so soone, rather approacht too late:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: The Capon burnes, the Pig fals from the spit;

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: The clocke hath strucken twelue vpon the bell:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: My Mistris made it one vpon my cheeke:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: She is so hot because the meate is colde:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: The meate is colde, because you come not home:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: You come not home, because you haue no stomacke:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: You haue no stomacke, hauing broke your fast:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: But we that know what 'tis to fast and pray,

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Are penitent for your default to day.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Stop in your winde sir, tell me this I pray?

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Where haue you left the mony that I gaue you.

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Oh sixe pence that I had a wensday last,

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: To pay the Sadler for my Mistris crupper:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: The Sadler had it Sir, I kept it not.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: I am not in a sportiue humor now:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Tell me, and dally not, where is the monie?

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: We being strangers here, how dar'st thou trust

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: So great a charge from thine owne custodie.

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: I pray you iest sir as you sit at dinner:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: I from my Mistris come to you in post:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: If I returne I shall be post indeede.

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: For she will scoure your fault vpon my pate:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Me thinkes your maw, like mine, should be your cooke,

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: And strike you home without a messenger

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Come {% italic: Dromio %}, come, these iests are out of season,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Reserue them till a merrier houre then this:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Where is the gold I gaue in charge to thee?

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: To me sir? why you gaue no gold to me?

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Come on sir knaue, haue done your foolishnes,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: And tell me how thou hast dispos'd thy charge.

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: My charge was but to fetch you fró the Mart

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Home to your house, the {% italic: Phoenix %} sir, to dinner;

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: My Mistris and her sister staies for you.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Now as I am a Christian answer me,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: In what safe place you haue bestow'd my monie;

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Or I shall breake that merrie sconce of yours

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: That stands on tricks, when I am vndispos'd:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Where is the thousand Markes thou hadst of me?

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: I haue some markes of yours vpon my pate:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Some of my Mistris markes vpon my shoulders:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: But not a thousand markes betweene you both.

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: If I should pay your worship those againe,

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Perchance you will not beare them patiently.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Thy Mistris markes? what Mistris slaue hast thou?

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Your worships wife, my Mistris at the {% italic: Phoenix %};

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: She that doth fast till you come home to dinner:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: And praies that you will hie you home to dinner.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: What wilt thou flout me thus vnto my face

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Being forbid? There take you that sir knaue.

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: What meane you sir, for God sake hold your ( hands:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Nay, and you will not sir, Ile take my heeles.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Vpon my life by some deuise or other,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: The villaine is ore‑wrought of all my monie.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: They say this towne is full of cosenage:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: As nimble Iuglers that deceiue the eie:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Darke working Sorcerers that change the minde:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Soule‑killing Witches, that deforme the bodie:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Disguised Cheaters, prating Mountebankes;

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: And manie such like liberties of sinne:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: If it proue so, I will be gone the sooner:

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Ile to the Centaur to goe seeke this slaue,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: I greatly feare my monie is not safe.

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: Neither my husband nor the slaue return'd,

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: That in such haste I sent to seeke his Master?

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: Sure {% italic: Luciana %} it is two a clocke.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Perhaps some Merchant hath inuited him,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: And from the Mart he's somewhere gone to dinner:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Good Sister let vs dine, and neuer fret;

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: A man is Master of his libertie:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Time is their Master, and when they see time,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: They'll goe or come; if so, be patient Sister.

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: Why should their libertie then ours be more?

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Because their businesse still lies out adore.

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: Looke when I serue him so, he takes it thus.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Oh, know he is the bridle of your will.

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: There's none but asses will be bridled so.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Why, headstrong liberty is lasht with woe:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: There's nothing situate vnder heauens eye,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: But hath his bound in earth, in sea, in skie.

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowles

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Are their males subiects, and at their controules:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Man more diuine, the Master of all these,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Lord of the wide world, and wilde watry seas,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Indued with intellectuall sence and soules,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Of more preheminence then fish and fowles,

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Are masters to their females, and their Lords:

lines.speaker: Luc.
lines.text: Then let your will attend on their accords.

lines.speaker: Adri.
lines.text: This seruitude makes you to keepe vnwed.

lines.speaker: Luci.

lines.text: But had he such a Chaine of thee, or no?

lines.speaker: Gold.
lines.text: He had my Lord, and when he ran in heere,

lines.speaker: Gold.
lines.text: These people saw the Chaine about his necke.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Besides, I will be sworne these eares of mine,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Heard you confesse you had the Chaine of him,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: After you first forswore it on the Mart,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And thereupon I drew my sword on you:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And then you fled into this Abbey heere,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: From whence I thinke you are come by Miracle.

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: I neuer came within these Abbey wals,

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: Nor euer didst thou draw thy sword on me:

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: I neuer saw the Chaine, so helpe me heauen:

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: And this is false you burthen me withall.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Why what an intricate impeach is this?

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: I thinke you all haue drunke of {% italic: Circes %} cup:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: If heere you hous'd him, heere he would haue bin.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: If he were mad, he would not pleade so coldly:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: You say he din'd at home, the Goldsmith heere

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Denies that saying. Sirra, what say you?

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Sir he din'de with her there, at the Porpen­tine.

lines.speaker: Cur.
lines.text: He did, and from my finger snacht that Ring.

lines.speaker: E. Anti
lines.text: Tis true (my Liege) this Ring I had of her.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Saw'st thou him enter at the Abbey heere?

lines.speaker: Curt.
lines.text: As sure (my Liege) as I do see your Grace.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Why this is straunge: Go call the Abbesse hi‑

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: I thinke you are all mated, or starke mad.

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Most mighty Duke, vouchsafe me speak a word:

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Haply I see a friend will saue my life,

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: And pay the sum that may deliuer me.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Speake freely {% italic: Siracusian %} what thou wilt.

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: Is not your name sir call'd {% italic: Antipholus %}?

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: And is not that your bondman {% italic: Dromio %}?

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Within this houre I was his bondman sir,

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: But he I thanke him gnaw'd in two my cords,

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Now am I {% italic: Dromio %}, and his man, vnbound.

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: I am sure you both of you remember me.

lines.speaker: Dro.
lines.text: Our selues we do remember sir by you:

lines.speaker: Dro.
lines.text: For lately we were bound as you are now.

lines.speaker: Dro.
lines.text: You are not {% italic: Pinches %} patient, are you sir?

lines.speaker: Father.
lines.text: Why looke you strange on me? you know

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: I neuer saw you in my life till now.

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Oh! griefe hath chang'd me since you saw me last,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Neither.

lines.speaker: Fat.
lines.text: {% italic: Dromio %}, nor thou?

lines.speaker: Dro.
lines.text: No trust me sir, nor I.

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: I am sure thou dost?

lines.speaker: E. Dromio.
lines.text: I sir, but I am sure I do not, and whatso‑

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: Not know my voice, oh times extremity {% italic: Antipholus. %}

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: I neuer saw my Father in my life.

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: But seuen yeares since, in {% italic: Siracusa %} boy

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Thou know'st we parted, but perhaps my sonne,

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Thou sham'st to acknowledge me in miserie.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: The Duke, and all that know me in the City,

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: Can witnesse with me that it is not so.

lines.speaker: Ant.
lines.text: I ne're saw {% italic: Siracusa %} in my life.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: I tell thee {% italic: Siracusian %}, twentie yeares

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Haue I bin Patron to {% italic: Antipholus %},

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: During which time, he ne're saw {% italic: Siracusa %}:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.

lines.speaker: Abbesse.
lines.text: Most mightie Duke, behold a man much

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: I see two husbands, or mine eyes deceiue me.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: One of these men is {% italic: genius %} to the other:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: And so of these, which is the naturall man,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: And which the spirit? Who deciphers them?

lines.speaker: S.Dromio.
lines.text: I Sir am {% italic: Dromio %}, command him away.

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: I Sir am {% italic: Dromio %}, pray let me stay.

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: {% italic: Egeon %} art thou not? or else his ghost.

lines.speaker: S.Drom.
lines.text: Oh my olde Master, who hath bound him

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: Who euer bound him, I will lose his bonds,

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: And gaine a husband by his libertie:

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: Speake olde {% italic: Egeon %}, if thou bee'st the man

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: That hadst a wife once call'd & {% italic: Æmilia %},

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: That bore thee at a burthen two faire sonnes?

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: Oh if thou bee'st the same {% italic: Egeon %}, speake:

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: And speake vnto the same & {% italic: Æmilia %}.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Why heere begins his Morning storie right:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: These two {% italic: Antipholus %}, these two so like,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: And these two {% italic: Dromio's %}, one in semblance:

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Besides her vrging of her wracke at sea,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: These are the parents to these children,

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Which accidentally are met together.

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: If I dreame not, thou art & {% italic: Æmilia %},

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: If thou art she, tell me, where is that sonne

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: That floated with thee on the fatall rafte.

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: By men of {% italic: Epidamium %}, he, and I,

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: And the twin {% italic: Dromio %}, all were taken vp;

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: But by and by, rude Fishermen of {% italic: Corinth %}

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: By force tooke {% italic: Dromio %}, and my sonne from them,

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: And me they left with those of {% italic: Epidamium. %}

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: What then became of them, I cannot tell:

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: I, to this fortune that you see mee in.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: {% italic: Antipholus %} thou cam'st from {% italic: Corinth %} first.

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: No sir, not I, I came from {% italic: Siracuse. %}

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: Stay, stand apart, I know not which is which.

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: I came from {% italic: Corinth %} my most gracious Lord

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: And I with him.

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: Brought to this Town by that most famous

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: Duke {% italic: Menaphon %} your most renowned Vnckle.

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: Which of you two did dine with me to day?

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: I, gentle Mistris.

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: And are not you my husband?

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: No, I say nay to that.

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: And so do I, yet did she call me so:

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: And this faire Gentlewoman her sister heere

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: Did call me brother. What I told you then,

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: I hope I shall haue leisure to make good,

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: If this be not a dreame I see and heare.

lines.speaker: Goldsmith.
lines.text: That is the Chaine sir, which you had of

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: I thinke it be sir, I denie it not.

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: And you sir for this Chaine arrested me.

lines.speaker: Gold.
lines.text: I thinke I did sir, I deny it not.

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: I sent you monie sir to be your baile

lines.speaker: Adr.
lines.text: By {% italic: Dromio %}, but I thinke he brought it not.

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: No, none by me.

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: This purse of Duckets I receiu'd from you,

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: And {% italic: Dromio %} my man did bring them me:

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: I see we still did meete each others man,

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: And I was tane for him, and he for me,

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: And thereupon these errors are arose.

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: These Duckets pawne I for my father heere.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: It shall not neede, thy father hath his life.

lines.speaker: Cur.
lines.text: Sir I must haue that Diamond from you.

lines.speaker: E. Ant.
lines.text: There take it, and much thanks for my good

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: Renowned Duke, vouchsafe to take the paines

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: To go with vs into the Abbey heere,

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: And heare at large discoursed all our fortunes,

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: And all that are assembled in this place:

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: That by this simpathized one daies error

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: Haue suffer'd wrong. Goe, keepe vs companie,

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: And we shall make full satisfaction.

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: Thirtie three yeares haue I but gone in trauaile

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: Of you my sonnes, and till this present houre

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: My heauie burthen are deliuered:

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: The Duke my husband, and my children both,

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: And you the Kalenders of their Natiuity,

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: Go to a Gossips feast, and go with mee,

lines.speaker: Abb.
lines.text: After so long greefe such Natiuitie.

lines.speaker: Duke.
lines.text: With all my heart, Ile Gossip at this feast.

lines.speaker: S. Dro.
lines.text: Mast. shall I fetch your stuffe from shipbord?

lines.speaker: E. An.
lines.text: {% italic: Dromio %}, what stuffe of mine hast thou imbarkt.

lines.speaker: S. Dro.
lines.text: Your goods that lay at host sir in the Centaur.

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: He speakes to me, I am your master {% italic: Dromio %}.

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: Come go with vs, wee'l looke to that anon,

lines.speaker: S. Ant.
lines.text: Embrace thy brother there, reioyce with him.

lines.speaker: S. Dro.
lines.text: There is a fat friend at your masters house,

lines.speaker: S. Dro.
lines.text: That kitchin'd me for you to day at dinner:

lines.speaker: S. Dro.
lines.text: She now shall be my sister, not my wife,

lines.speaker: E. D.
lines.text: Me thinks you are my glasse, & not my brother:

lines.speaker: E. D.
lines.text: I see by you, I am a sweet‑fac'd youth,

lines.speaker: E. D.
lines.text: Will you walke in to see their gossipping?

lines.speaker: S. Dro.
lines.text: Not I sir, you are my elder.

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: That's a question, how shall we trie it.

lines.speaker: S. Dro.
lines.text: Wee'l draw Cuts for the Signior, till then,

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: Nay then thus:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: We came into the world like brother and brother:

lines.speaker: E. Dro.
lines.text: And now let's go hand in hand, not one before another.
